Yes, Bitcoin ($BTC ) mining is still alive in 2025 - but it has separated into 2 distinct paths:  üîπ Solo mining is now mostly symbolic: with today‚Äôs difficulty and industrial-scale hashpower, finding a block independently is nearly impossible.  üî∏ Pool mining remains viable because it converts probabilistic block rewards into steady, predictable payouts.  That‚Äôs why your payout economics depend almost entirely on the pool you choose üí∞  Modern pools compete on financial efficiency - consistent FPPS rates, reliable payout schedules, and integrated tools for managing mined BTC now matter more than sheer hashrate.  üìä For a clear comparison of how leading pools perform across these metrics, this follow-up analysis is worth exploring: https://coinmarketcap.com/community/articles/6929ad845ba9f81e8fd24773/   #BTC Price Analysis#  #Bitcoin  #Bitcoin Price Prediction: What is Bitcoins next move?#

$BTC didn‚Äôt just ‚Äúdump‚Äù, it was slammed by a wave of massive sell‚Äëoffs from major players. Binance unloaded 4,000 BTC, Coinbase dropped 5,675 BTC, Fidelity offloaded 3,288 BTC, Strategy sold 3,823 BTC, and Wintermute dumped 1,793 BTC. That‚Äôs over $2 billion in selling pressure hitting the market almost simultaneously, and they‚Äôre still unloading, which looks a lot less like coincidence and a lot more like coordinated insider action. The timing is even more suspicious: $BTC and $ETH pumped on bullish PCE data, then suddenly reversed so violently that nearly $100 million in longs were liquidated in just 30 minutes. Hard to call that ‚Äúorganic market movement‚Äù when the big players are all pulling the trigger at once.

What Is a CSR (Critical Support Reversal)?


A CSR is a structural price level where market control can shift decisively from sellers to buyers. Unlike a standard support zone, a CSR is defined by context, behaviour, and higher-timeframe significance.


A CSR typically forms when:


1Ô∏è‚É£ Price reaches the deepest point of a downtrend and sellers show exhaustion
‚Äì Volume fades
‚Äì Momentum weakens
‚Äì Candles lose follow-through


2Ô∏è‚É£ Buyers create the first meaningful counter-move of the trend
A CSR is confirmed only when structure breaks‚Äîsuch as a higher low, higher high, or strong bullish impulse.


3Ô∏è‚É£ The zone aligns with HTF confluences
These often include demand clusters, wedge-support intersections, HTF fib levels, previous accumulation ranges, or liquidity pivots.


‚∏ª


Why CSRs Matter


A CSR is the point where the market effectively says:
‚ÄúSellers are losing control; buyers are stepping in.‚Äù


CSRs offer:


‚úî High-probability accumulation zones
‚úî Early signals of macro reversals
‚úî Strong entries for swing setups
‚úî Clear invalidation if the zone fails


A successful CSR often transitions price from controlled descent into accelerated expansion. A failed CSR usually opens the door to lower liquidity zones.


‚∏ª


How I Use CSRs


For me, a CSR isn‚Äôt just support‚Äîit‚Äôs a structural pivot where:


‚Ä¢ Selling pressure exhausts
‚Ä¢ Buyers interrupt the trend
‚Ä¢ Liquidity conditions favour expansion
‚Ä¢ The HTF structure can reset


This is why CSR reactions frequently produce some of the strongest early-stage reversal moves across altcoins.


‚∏ª

Highlighting lower wage workers for a brutally honest analogy for the labor market. 
Obviously a small portion of people in this demographic would see this. But if you have family members who seek crypto and not sure how to dive into such decisions, this may help. 
This decision is like an industrial worker with a family needing a reliable car for work (analogy: stable transportation = stable finances).
üìâ Scenario 1: Investing money needed for immediate needs
 * Analogy: You use the money set aside for the car payment/insurance to buy a race car (crypto) instead.
 * Outcome: If the race car wins, you get rich, but if it breaks down, you can't get to work and lose your income‚Äîa high-risk gamble when stability is critical. This is generally a bad idea.
‚úÖ Scenario 2: Investing small, extra savings
 * Analogy: You save a little extra each month and buy a small, potentially valuable collectible (crypto).
 * Outcome: If it appreciates, it's a bonus. If it doesn't, it doesn't hurt your ability to pay for the essential car. It's a way to seek higher returns with funds you can afford to lose, but it won't solve systemic low wages. This is acceptable for diversification.
In short, don't invest money you need to live on (like rent or food) in something as volatile as crypto; only use true disposable income.
